raw_text:
Fannie Mae 'should restate books'
 
 US mortgage company Fannie Mae should restate its earnings, a move that is likely to put a billion-dollar dent in its accounts, watchdogs have said.
 
 The Securities & Exchange Commission accused Fannie Mae of using techniques that "did not comply in material respects" with accounting standards. Fannie Mae last month warned that some records were incorrect. The other main US mortgage firm Freddie Mac restated earnings by $5bn (£2.6bn) last year after a probe of its books. The SEC's comments are likely to increase pressure on Congress to strengthen supervision of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
 
 The two firms are key parts of the US financial system and effectively underwrite the mortgage market, financing nearly half of all American house purchases and dealing actively in bonds and other financial instruments. The investigation of Freddie Mac in June 2003 sparked concerns about the wider health of the industry and raised questionsmarks over the role of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight (OFHEO), the industry's main regulator. Having been pricked into action, the OFHEO turned its attention to Fannie May and in September this year said that the firm had tweaked its books to spread earnings more smoothly across quarters and play down the amount of risk it had taken on. The SEC found similar problems. The watchdog's chief accountant Donald Nicolaisen said that "Fannie Mae's methodology of assessing, measuring and documenting hedge ineffectiveness was inadequate and was not supported" by generally accepted accounting principles.

The Securities & Exchange Commission found similar issues at Freddie Mac.
The two firms underwrite the US mortgage market, deal in financial instruments, and have a significant impact on home purchases.
Their recent restatements of earnings were prompted by concerns about their financial health.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The U.S. Treasury Department criticized Fannie Mae as "not compliant" with accounting standards due to potential misstatements in its financial statements.

The Securities & Exchange Commission accused Fannie Mae of using improper techniques, while Freddie Mac also faced an investigation that led to concerns about the health of the mortgage industry and questions regarding regulatory oversight by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight (OFHEO).
Both firms restated earnings last year, with F Annie Mae showing a $5 billion increase in its financial statements and Freddie Mac only increasing their 2003 earnings by $187 million.
These findings highlight potential issues in their accounting practices that could pressure Congress to strengthen supervision.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Securities & Exchange Commission has accused the US mortgage company Fawnie Mae of using techniques that did not meet standard accounting standards, leading to a bill of $1 billion in damages on their accounts.

The main US mortgage firm Freddie Mac was also threatened with supervision restructuring in 2003 after it was found to have misreported half of its books, leading to concerns about the wider health of the industry and questions over the role of OFHEO.
In September 2004, the SEC's chief accountant, Donald Nicolaisen, expressed serious doubts about Fawnie Mae's methodology, which had resulted in a bill of $1 billion in damages on their accounts.
The watchdog is now calling for an investigation into the wider mortgage industry to look at how they are regulated and overseen.

This situation follows similar actions by Freddie Mac where it restated its earnings last year after an investigation prompted concerns about the wider health of the industry and raised questions marks over the role of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight (OFHEO), the main regulator within the sector.

Fannie Mae has since adjusted its books to spread earnings more smoothly across quarters and reduce risk exposure, in response to the SEC's findings, with similar issues identified by the watchdog's chief accountant, Donald Nicolaisen.

The SEC's findings are expected to intensify calls for Congress to enhance oversight of both Fannie Mae and its sibling firm, Freddie Mac.

The SEC and OFHEO discovered that Fannie Mae manipulated its financial records to mask risk more effectively and evenly across quarters.
